text: Yeah, it’s possible given how the timers are sampled. Do you have a MWE?

elements.text: Yeah, it’s possible given how the timers are sampled. Do you have a MWE?

text: Threading definitely messes it up currently.. I’m working on a PR to make the compile timers thread-local

elements.text: Threading definitely messes it up currently.. I’m working on a PR to make the compile timers thread-local

text: The reason it can happen is that we prioritize accuracy in the main timer by making that the tightest thing around the code under test

elements.text: The reason it can happen is that we prioritize accuracy in the main timer by making that the tightest thing around the code under test

text: The compile timer wraps around that, so what might be happening is some invalidation of the compile timer samplers... or you’ve got threading going on..

elements.text: The compile timer wraps around that, so what might be happening is some invalidation of the compile timer samplers... or you’ve got threading going on..

text: I don't have a MWE. It happens when I run the `Octavian.jl` (<https://github.com/JuliaLinearAlgebra/Octavian.jl>) test suite locally with four threads and with code coverage enabled. Let me see if I can reproduce it with one thread.

elements.text: I don't have a MWE. It happens when I run the
) test suite locally with four threads and with code coverage enabled. Let me see if I can reproduce it with one thread.

text:
With coverage enabled and four threads, I consistently see it happen.

However, it does not seem to happen with coverage enabled and one thread.
